descriptive_name: Mixture of 2,4-dinitro-6-octylphenyl crotonate and 2,6-dinitro-4-octylphenyl crotonate (octyl=1-methylheptyl,1-ethylhexyl,1-propylpentyl); Dinocap; DPC

acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on the rabbit LD50 (dermal route) value of 9,400mg/kg (RTECS (2006)).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "liquid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_vapor.rationale: Based on the rat LC50 value of 24ppm (4 hours), calculated from the testing data of rat LC50 (inhalation of vapour) of 0.36mg/L (4 hours) (RTECS (2006)), was lower than the saturated vapour concentration (52,800ppm) under a saturated vapour pressure of 0.00533mPa (25degC) (Howard (1997)), the substance was considered as "vapour containing substantially no mist" and was classified based on standard values expressed in ppm.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the LD50 value of 829mg/kg calculated from the rat LD50 (oral route) of 980mg/kg, 950mg/kg, 1,190mg/kg (HSDB (2006)) and 766mg/kg (RTECS (2006)).

carcinogenicity.rationale: Classification not possible based on expert judgment in the absence of existing classification, though some toxicity data are available.

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term

explosives.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data on decomposition energy, though the substance contains nitro groups with its oxygen budget calculated at -184. According to ICSC (2004), Dinocap (mixing ratio of isomers unknown) may decompose when heated above 32degC.

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases
flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data, though Dinocap (mixing ratio of isomers unknown) is classified as flammable by ICSC (2004).

flammable_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on the absence of data on multi-generation mutagenicity tests and germ cell mutagenicity tests in vivo, and negative data on somatic cell mutagenicity tests in vivo (chromosome aberration tests), described in JMPR (1989) and JMPR (1998).

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data, though being organic compounds containing oxygen bound to the elements other than carbon and hydrogen.

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: No data available. Considered non-pyrophoric when in contact with air at ordinary temperatures since the substance is widely used as fungicides, acaricides, etc. for fruits, vines, vegetables and house plants (Dinocap, mixing ratio of isomers unknown (HSDB, 2006)).

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

reproductive_toxicity.hazard_statement: May damage fertility or the unborn child
reproductive_toxicity.rationale: Based on the evidence of increased pup mortality and fetal malformation (cleft palate, abnormal inner ear) at non-parentally toxic doses in mouse teratogenicity studies, described in JMPR (1989).

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available.

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data, though the substance contains nitro groups with explosive properties. According to ICSC (2004), Dinocap (mixing ratio of isomers unknown) may decompose when heated above 32degC.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on the description of the human health effects (exposure duration unknown) (HSDB (2006)): "They are only moderately irritating to the skin and mucous membranes."

skin_sensitizer.hazard_statement: May cause an allergic skin reaction
skin_sensitizer.rationale: Based on the description of the human health effects (HSDB (2006) and ICSC (J) (1997)): "Skin sensitization: positive."

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Containing no metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At)

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement:
Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (liver)
May cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (kidney)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the evidence from animal studies: "necrosis was found in the liver" (JMPR (1998)), "histological changes were noted in the liver and kidneys" (HSDB (2006)). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Categories 1 and 2.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
